Where Alabama Senate candidates Doug Jones, Tommy Tuberville stand on abortion, gun rightsBrian Lyman
 
| Montgomery AdvertiserAbortion and gun rights have been perennials in Alabama politics. Republican Senate nominee Tommy Tuberville recently rolled out an ad featuring a woman expressing regret for an abortion in her teen years, saying Democratic U.S. Sen. Doug Jones should “seek forgiveness” for his support for abortion rights.The ad doesn’t say what the candidate’s views are. The former Auburn head football coach says he is anti-abortion, and last year said he was “all for” a law that banned abortion in almost all non-medical circumstances in Alabama, including cases of sexual assault. Tuberville's campaign declined to answer questions from the Advertiser about abortion and gun rights. The Republican nominee has also declined to answer questions about COVID-19 and climate change. Jones supports abortion rights, writing in response to questions that abortion “is a deeply personal decision between a woman, her health care provider and her faith.”“There are deep disagreements on the issue of abortion and I respect those who oppose abortion for religious or personal reasons,” Jones wrote. “But while some candidates might deny the complexity of this issue — and appeal to folks in a politically self-serving way that ignores the facts — this issue is rarely so simple for those who face this gut-wrenching situation.”More: Where Doug Jones, Tommy Tuberville stand on addressing the COVID-19 outbreakJones does oppose late-term abortions, which are rare, and wrote in response to questions that he “does not support the use of taxpayer dollars to fund abortions.”  Jones, like other Democrats, has voted for appropriations bills that include the Hyde Amendment, which bans abortion funding in most federal health insurance programs and is routinely included in those bills. Jones said in 2018 he “does not support any changes” to current bans on federal abortion spending, one way or the other. Jones has broken with abortion rights supporters on other issues, including voting to confirm some of President Donald Trump’s judicial nominees and for a bill that drew strong opposition from the country’s leading organization for gynecologists and obstetricians. More: Where Alabama U.S. Senate candidates Doug Jones, Tommy Tuberville stand on climate changeThe senator also broadly supports gun rights, writing that he “wouldn’t want someone to vote against my right to bear arms or take my guns away” and stressing work to protect hunting and wildlife resources. Jones does support improvements to the background check system and closing loopholes in the existing system. More: Read Doug Jones' 9 responses to questions on abortion and gun rightsAbortion Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett discusses Roe v. WadeSupreme Court nominee Judge Amy Coney Barrett discussed Roe v. Wade at Jacksonville University’s Public Policy Institute in 2016.USA TODAY HandoutThe abortion rate in the United States peaked in 1981 at 29.3 per 1,000 women, according to the Guttmacher Institute, which collects data on reproductive issues and supports abortion rights. Since then, abortions in the United States have gone into a steady decline. Between 2011 and 2017, the rate fell from 16.9 per 1,000 women to 13.5 per 1,000. Alabama’s abortion rate, which is lower than the national average, also fell during that time, from 8.3 abortions per 1,000 women in 2011 to 6.4 in 2017. The Guttmacher Institute says a broader decline in pregnancies appears to be the main reason for the fall in the abortion rate, though it said state-imposed restrictions are also playing a factor. Jones said the best way to reduce abortion is to “improve the quality of life and economic outlook for women.” To do that, Jones wrote, he supported measures to raise the minimum wage and improve maternal health care, in particular disparities between white and Black Alabamians. According to NARAL Pro-Choice America, an abortion rights group, Jones voted for their positions 69% of the time in 2019. Most of the breaks occurred when Jones voted to confirm judges the organization opposed. Jones also voted to advance a bill to provide criminal penalties for withdrawal of medical care from a child who is born during an abortion or attempted abortion. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists opposed the bill, saying it could criminalize the induction of labor in cases of fetal abnormalities. Jones declined to say if he would vote for an otherwise-qualified Supreme Court nominee who may not share his views on abortion. The senator cited his statement last month that he would not vote for any Supreme Court nominee before the election, saying the current process was moving too quickly. “Mitch McConnell’s move to rush the confirmation of this nominee may very well cause irreparable harm to the confidence that the American people should have in the independence of the Supreme Court,” he said.Jones wrote that he supports adoption and foster programs, as well as “extending” current federal programs that make contraceptives cheaper and more accessible for women as a way to reduce unwanted pregnancies and the abortion rate.“Too many people in this state want to stand on a moral soapbox about this issue and ignore the fact that human beings act in certain ways that are often irresponsible or uninformed,” he wrote. “I believe that better education and easier and cheaper access to contraception would reduce unwanted pregnancies.”GunsGiffords pushes gun reform during virtual DNCGabby Giffords, the former Arizona congresswoman who was shot and has since become a national advocate for tighter gun control, was among a lengthy list of Democratic speakers Wednesday for the third night of the party’s national convention. (Aug 19).APGun ownership in Alabama has declined slightly over the past 30 years. A Rand Corporation study released in April found that roughly 50% of  all households in Alabama in 2016 had a firearm, down from 63% in 1990 but a bit higher than the 48% estimated to have owned guns in 2010. But in Alabama, deaths from firearms are higher than average. According to the CDC, Alabama had 21.8 deaths by firearm per 100,000 people in 2018, second only to Mississippi.  Alabama’s 1,064 deaths from firearms that year were higher than the 821 reported in New York, a state with almost four times the population of Alabama. More than half of gun deaths in Alabama are deaths by suicide; firearms were present in 70% of recorded suicides in the state in 2016, according to the Alabama Department of Public Health. In a 2019 interview with the Daily Mlountain Eagle, Tuberville said he is “not for any form or fashion of gun control” and spoke of “mental health treatment” to address gun violence. But he gave no specific statement as to what he would support or oppose on that front. Jones wrote that he supports red flag laws, in which a family can get a court order to temporarily take firearms from a person threatening harm to himself or others. Jones also reiterated his support for Medicaid expansion, which could make mental health services more accessible. He also said there needs to be destigmatization of mental health issues “so that no one feels uncomfortable talking about their pain.” The senator wrote he supports raising the minimum age for “certain semi-automatic weapons” to 21, though he opposes raising the age limit for the purchase of other firearms. Jones also said he supports closing the “Charleston loophole,” allowing gun purchasers to obtain a gun after three days whether a background check has been completed. He also supports closing what is called the “boyfriend loophole.” Federal law bans domestic abusers from owning guns, but only if the victim was a spouse, someone they lived with or someone with whom the abuser shared a child. It does not cover domestic abusers in relationships outside those definitions. “Closing this loophole would help prevent domestic violence deaths,” Jones wrote. Contact Montgomery Advertiser reporter Brian Lyman at 334-240-0185 or blyman@gannett.com.
